subject: RE: [junit] Is coverage important?  RE: Test Coverage Analysis To ol For Junit
msgSnippet: Hi, I would like to make some comments about Is coverage important? : Greg, as far as i understand your e-mail, you are telling that coverage is not so
messageBody:
Hi,

I would like to make some comments about "Is coverage important?":

Greg, as far as i understand your e-mail, you are telling that coverage is
not so important, but at the same time, i find in your arguments a very
important reason to use coverage tools: "Only use Coverage tools to reveal
something that could break"... mmmm, isn't it that the reason of using
JUnit?, so if we have a tool that helps JUnit to acomplish that task why
shouldn't we use it?
On the other hand, i agree that Coverage as a metric is not very valuable,
but that's the same case for "number of Unit Tests" and "number of passing
Functional Tests": i am afraid we can make tests that cover the whole
application and at the same time are completly useless (not really testing
the application), but also, we can make tons of (passing) tests that only
cover a small part of the application.
So, should we stop using those quality metrics in projects because they are
inaccurate? my understanding is that the quality metrics are there to be
used, sometimes they are very useful and sometimes not, but that is the same
business as using JUnit (i have never believed that getting a green light
after passing all the tests is an indicator of having the perfect
application)
Babu, you mentioned: "Coverage metrics shouldn't be used to measure quality
of the product instead it should be used to measure quality of tests that
you developed (i.e. measure effectivenes of tests)", but aren't we measuring
quality of the product when we measure quality of tests?
I think what we are all afraid is of Steve's statement: "If you're really
writing code test-first you should find that you hit 98-99% coverage without
breaking into a sweat." I have never liked imposed coverage percentages
because not all the applications can be covered in the same way (some
applications are very easy to be covered and some others are impossible),
and because usually the developers start to trick with the tests just to get
that percentages (and usually that tricks are not very "quality-oriented"
and at the end they are a waste of time)
I believe quality metrics are indicators and not filters between good and
bad applications.
Finally, i agree completly with Michael (even if i use JProbe and not
TestMentor :-)

my apologizes for this long e-mail,
--Carlos--

> We find using simple code coverage (method entry profiling)
> is a cheap and
> easy way to double-check your tests and helps ensure you
> really did test
> everything you intended to test with your test cases. I believe Joseph
> Pelrine, possibly in this lecture
> http://oopsla.acm.org/ap/tutorials/tut66.html, mentioned
> several groups
> using XP who thought they were doing a fine job of writing
> tests, only to
> find on running their tests under a code coverage profiler
> (SilverMark's
> Test Mentor with code coverage profiling turned on), that
> they had missed a
> number of important functional variations/methods. The way I
> look at it, we
> test because we admit we are fallible. Any tool or technique
> that, when used
> properly, can help guard against that fallibility when we
> write our tests
> must be a good thing.

> > Analysis To ol For Junit
> >
> >
> > Is coverage really that important? The directive is to "Test
> > everything that could possibly break", not "Test everything".
> >
> > Unit Tests give you great benefits in productivity and quality.
> > I have worked on XP teams that measured both quality and
> > productivity. Unit Testing and XP does improve both! However,
> > there comes a point where more Unit Tests only marginally
> > increases quality while not increasing productivity (even
> > negatively impacting productivity). Developers should question
> > the value of creating more Unit Tests. If you are not careful,
> > you can get into a "Test everything" mode and kill productivity.
> >
> > Since Coverage metrics can lead the team to focus on "Test
> > Everything", it isn't a great measurement. Instead, focus on
> > "things that could break" and you will continue to gain both
> > increased productivity and quality. Only use Coverage tools to
> > reveal something that could break. Using coverage as a metric is
> > a poor practice. I suggest using quality metrics instead (i.e.
> > number of Unit Tests and number of passing Functional Tests)
> >
